values:
Hey dudes, you can check me out at READIN. Not here so much, I just created this account so I can comment on Heebie's and Martha's journals without having to immediately post a second comment identifying myself. And Julia's too, come to that.

So I use it for commenting mostly, and posting on communities, and occasionally I put a cool video or a random thought up. But my real blogging occurs over at READIN.

Here's an interesting meme: Post a picture in my comments of what you think describes me when you think about what/who I am. No matter how surreal or plain. Give no written explanation. Just an image. (Optional: Post this in your journal and see what images you get.) Thanks for the idea, !

So listen, all of you should check out this new record... Slow evening at home with cup of tea and listening to the kind of music that totally fills your mind up. And also reading "The Hobbit" at intervals. Pleasant.

Title for a review of this record: "Notes toward Wakefulness" Update: Whole record available as an audio stream here: http://store.yeproc.com/album.php?id=14104
Longish story -- the short version is, I grew up in Modesto -- I love the "The Kenosha Kid" section of Gravity's Rainbow -- so...

Here are the rules (via Sketchguy):

1 - Go to Wikipedia. Hit “random”
or click en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Random
The first random Wikipedia article you get is the name of your band.

2 - Go to Quotations Page and select "random quotations"
or click www.quotationspage.com/random.php3
The last four or five words of the very last quote on the page is the title of your first album.

3 - Go to Flickr and click on “explore the last seven days”
or click www.flickr.com/explore/interesting/7days
Third picture, no matter what it is, will be your album cover.

4 - Use Photoshop or similar to put it all together.
...Wow: look at this one from cleek.

I was walking down the hallway at work and looked at the elevator; I thought the sign said "In case of fire do not confuse elevator with stairway". Also: The title of this article admits of two very different readings.

Driving to work this morning, I was going to merge into the left lane. Looked in my rear view mirror and saw nobody over there, did not bother to look over my shoulder. Started moving over. Then, when I was about half way over the line, moved back into the right lane -- I'm not sure why! And once I was back in my lane, the car that had been in my blind spot moved past me. Weird that he did not honk or anything; I'm glad I stopped merging before I collided with him though.

When you see this, post your favorite poem "MY CORPSE and I" by Nicanor Parra (tr. Liz Werner) MY CORPSE and I understand each other marvelously my corpse asks me: do you believe in God? and I respond with a hearty NO my corpse asks: do you believe in the government? and I respond with the hammer and sickle my corpse asks: do you believe in the police? and I respond with a punch in the face then he gets up out of his coffin and we go arm in arm to the altar

Check out the washboard tie! This is J-Dog and Elijah Wald, playing in Santa Monica. This one's nice too: Ralph Litwin, Al Podber, Lenny Podber, and Giboney Whyte on Ralph's TV show. Their CD is available here.

May old potatoes be forgot,
Whether scalloped, mashed, or fried?
May old potatoes be forgot,
And the taste of turpentine.

The taste of turpentine, my boys,
The taste of turpentine,
Should old potatoes be forgot,
And the taste of turpentine.
This cartoon from beatonna is just hilarious. I didn't know who Pierre Berton is, so I looked him up and found he had some useful advice for me:
Needs to be created, I just have a title is all: "The Electric Oobleck Acid Test".

Yahoo should totally do a joint venture with BluRay, and call it HooRay.
(badum-ching)

This caught my eye on Colbert tonight.
<lj-embed id="24"/>
Via Matt Yglesias, who argues that copyright laws should be changed to allow this kind of thing:

Ok, this is at least very, very strange... kinda fun, too:

"Jesus is my Friend" by Sonseed

Lots more info about Sonseed, at Dougsploitation: including interviews.

It's really nice to get "Luminous Groove" (the new collection of Robyn Hitchcock and the Egyptians recordings) and put the "Element of Light" disc on the turntable. I had forgotten how impossibly lush his voice is. (Oh, one other thing: this statue is of Adamastor, and is in Lisbon. The statue is a central part of the setting for The Year of the Death of Ricardo Reis.)

I can't tell you how often the thought runs through my head, "There's something I'm supposed to be doing right now -- someone I need to meet or to call -- I've forgotten something at home that I said I would bring with me..." Just now I had the unsettling thought: What if these instances are cumulative? At some point in the future it will come to pass that all the times I've had this type of thought are converted into concrete missed appointments or opportunities or forgotten promises, I will be confronted with this abyss of past worry made real and called on to justify it.

Hey, unrelated but you ought to read Ted Chiang's short story "The Merchant and the Alchemist's Gate" -- it's really good and there is a lot to take away from it.

Never been a big fan of Cocker, but man, this is all right:

<lj-embed id="20"/>

Who is that playing guitar? He is amazing.
...Aha! It is Leon Russell.
The Boswell Sisters have got 'em; now thanks to Heebie-Geebie, I've got 'em too: There are a bunch of good Boswell Sisters videos on YouTube. Eddie Lang on guitar.

(No twindowlicker, I'm not stealing your alphabetical Choosday Chunes idea :0)) Meme passed along from The Luddite Robot: 1. Reply to this post and I'll assign you a letter. 2. List (and upload, if you feel like it) 5 songs that start with that letter. 3. Post them to your journal with these instructions. (I added "2a. Make sure they are all songs you have not listened to in a while -- the point of this exercise is to reacquaint yourself with your collection.") He gave me "C", here are my songs. 1. "Cajon Jam", by the Jazz Mandolin Project (No, that's not a misspelling of "Cajun": Cajon) from their 9/29/04 concert at Pour House Music Hall 2. "Canda Munani Ishkay" by Yarina, from their album Ñawi 3. "Can I Change My Mind" by Tyrone Davis 4. "Cedar Hill", by the Dave Grisman Quintet from their 10/3/97 concert at Sommerville Theater 5. "Chewin Chawin Gum" by the Carter Family
Come over to my place and wish me a happy one.

So I go into the breakroom this morning to get a cup of coffee; next to the coffee machine is a box of Chips Ahoy® cookies. As I help myself to a chocolate chip cookie I say in my best sailor voice, "Chips, ahoy!"

At the end of the concert last night, a surprise guest came out:
<lj-embed id="16" />
Check out Robyn's guitar solo toward the end. The sound quality is poor, it might not come through; but that was a fantastic solo.
Those are the only two words that could possibly describe this: Here is a longer version, which I can't embed.

Sid and Nanette know how to argue:

<lj-embed id="13" />

Oh no! (NSFW)

And lo! Bad Gods is updated today (well since I stopped checking it a couple weeks ago anyway), with an appropriate image.

My dad passed along a link to this video of "One Toke Over the Line" from the Lawrence Welk show. Too much.

<lj-embed id="10"/>
...from a search for "the modesto kid", is this one.

Here we are: me on viola and vocals, Jerry on guitar and vocals:

Weary Day

(by the Delmore Bros.)

The Louisville Burglar

(by the Iron Mountain String Band) Recorded 12/27 at Here's to the Arts in Maplewood.

From The Luddite Robot: I know very little about some of the people on my friends list. Some people I know relatively well. I read your journals, or we have something else in common, and we chat occasionally. Some of you I hardly know at all. Perhaps you lurk, for whatever reason. But you friended me, and I thank you for your interest in my words. But here's a thought: why not take this opportunity to tell me a little something about yourself. Any old thing at all. Just so the next time I see your name I can say: "Ah, there's so and so...they enjoy the savory aroma of monkey brains a la mode." I'd love it if every single person who friended me would do this. Yes, even you people who I know really well. Then post this in your own journal and see what gems of knowledge appear.

How do I know this? Back in the beginning of October or so, the company put a big bowl of mixed candies in the breakroom. The chocolate stuff quickly disappeared. Over the next month and a half, the bowl was repeatedly refilled, and the chocolates were eaten quickly each time. Since mid-November there has been a big bowl full of Tootsie Rolls and Bit-o-Honeys in the breakroom.
The singular form of "sheeple" is "sherson". (And the adjective is "eweman".)

(fragment)

Make up my alabaster soul -- and
Sigh, I've heard it all before, and
Drop your papers in the in-box on the floor.
Escape! My scarlet memory is
Too short -- it's decrepit, really
Gone, I'll never guess til it's too late.
Want to hear an arrangement of "Oh What A Beautiful Morning" I am working on? It is on my other blog.
Everybody be sure to check out Ellen's new blog, Teddy Bear in a Suitcase! Great writing about the traveling and reading she does with Sylvia.
I wake up this morning with the line running through my head, "...Just like what you eat is only half the digestive story!" Not sure what the lead-in to a line like that would be though.
Isn't there like sort of a general consensus out there that Pepperidge Farms Goldfish are better than Cheez-its? Because that seems really perverse to me.

I want to see this movie, though I'm not sure if I will, since my wife does not want to; but I'm finding it impossible to look at the title without hearing it sung to the tune of "No X-Mas for John Quays" by The Fall.

Outside the office window just now, Chris and I were watching a leafless tree with hundreds of crows sitting in the branches -- almost in unison they all swooped down and were standing on the ground under the tree -- then they all took off in this enormous black crowd and flew into the tree across the street. Mind-blowing to watch.

1. I was having breakfast the other day at Verona Diner and I noticed a clip-out coupon on the placemat for "Buy 1 bagel, get 1 free" at the nearby Bagelwich Deli. Ok, so that's a little bit funny -- then I looked at the fine print, which said "Second bagel of equal or lesser value", which struck me as pretty hilarious. -- As my brother put it, "Dude, don't try to get the special bagel for free."
  2. The Verona Diner is an excellent place to go for breakfast if (a) you like home fries cooked just right, and (b) you like being the only person under 60 in a fairly crowded restaurant. Both (a) and (b) apply for me, so I'm golden. (I used to always order fried eggs or scrambled eggs when I ate in a diner -- lately I've been ordering poached eggs.)
  3. DiPaolo's Bakery (right across the street from the Bagelwich) is a seriously awesome thing. Go there early in the morning and get Ciabatta still warm from the oven. Do it!
